channel.title: Cosmos
channel.description: A world where everyone holds the power to employ science and creativity for good.

item.title: Mind’s Eye: an audio tour of the Solar System
item.dc:creator: Lindsay
item.description: Albany Theatre garden monday 16th february – sunday 22nd february 10:00 – 2000 (drop in, indoor/outdoor activity) SHRINKING SPACE EXAMINES HUMANITY’S PLACE IN THE SOLAR SYSTEM BY INVITING ARTISTS, SCIENTISTS & ENGINEERS TO PARTICIPATE IN A FICTIONAL SPACE PROGRAMME. Let Mind’s Eye transport you from Deptford South East London, to the Read more…
item.content:encoded:
Albany Theatre garden

monday 16th february – sunday 22nd february

10:00 – 2000 (drop in, indoor/outdoor activity)

SHRINKING SPACE EXAMINES HUMANITY’S PLACE IN THE SOLAR SYSTEM BY INVITING ARTISTS, SCIENTISTS & ENGINEERS TO PARTICIPATE IN A FICTIONAL SPACE PROGRAMME.

Let Mind’s Eye transport you from Deptford South East London, to the furthest flung corners of our solar system.

As you enter, you’ll receive headphones and a pre-tuned iPod radio. Wander around the Albany Theatre Garden and find yourself pulled into the orbit of different areas representing Earth, Moon, Mercury, Mars, Venus, the Sun, Saturn, Rosetta mission and Voyager mission. Once you walk into the invisible “bubble” of a celestial body or mission, your headphones will tune into fascinating interviews and discussions with scientists, space explorers and celestial adventurers whose knowledge of the planet or star they are describing often represents a lifetime’s work.

Mind’s Eye has been made possible by the support of Brighton Digital Festival, Arts Council England, European Space Agency, NASA Goddard Space Flight Center and Little Atoms.

“The effect is bewitching, like floating through space itself, with only the occasional transmission back to earth for company.” Becky Hogge

item.title: The Intergalactic Travel Bureau
item.dc:creator: Lindsay
item.description: Intergalactic Travel Bureau Monday 16th February 2015 – 1200-1800 (DROP-IN) wednesday 18TH FEBRUARY 2015 – 1000-1800 (DROP-IN) ALBANY THEATRE (purple room) An asteroid is heading for London – it might be time to think about a little getaway – maybe as far, far away as possible? Welcome to the Intergalactic Travel Read more…
item.content:encoded:
Intergalactic Travel Bureau

Monday 16th February 2015 – 1200-1800 (DROP-IN)
wednesday 18TH FEBRUARY 2015 – 1000-1800 (DROP-IN)

ALBANY THEATRE (purple room)

An asteroid is heading for London – it might be time to think about a little getaway – maybe as far, far away as possible?

Welcome to the Intergalactic Travel Bureau, the resource for all your luxury space travel needs. We cater to your unique desires when selecting a destination. 

The Intergalactic Travel Bureau is a live, interactive experience that explores the incredible possibilities of space tourism. It’s a little bit like Virgin Galactic and Space X meet the Jetsons and Mad Men.

This February we invite you to come visit and let us plan your vacation to another planet! For shorter getaways, might we suggest a short stay on Earth’s moon. With gravity about one sixth that of the Earth, you can enjoy moon-jumping from the comfort of your climate controlled hotel room, while the moon’s synchronous rotation provides a constant view of our home planet from your hotel window.

If you’re serious about skiing, imagine flying down the black runs of Pluto. For those who enjoy scuba diving, we suggest searching for sea life in Europa’s chilly subsurface ocean. But these are just a handful of the numerous destinations both inside and outside Earth’s solar system, and our agents would be delighted to discuss all your options with you.

Once you have selected your destination, our agents will be happy to discuss pricing, time commitments, and logistics with you to make sure your vacation is ideal for you in every detail.

The Intergalactic Travel Bureau brings together space scientists, astronomers, science educators and actors to SMASHfestUK unique, personalised, immersive spac- vacation planning experiences.

item.title: Today, A Huge Asteroid Will Pass Very Close To Earth!
item.dc:creator: Lindsay
item.description: An asteroid measuring about a third of a mile (half a kilometer) in diameter will make a relatively close, but harmless pass by Earth Monday night, according to NASA. This mini-doc about the implications for earth if an asteroid were to collide with our planet, looks at how we share the Read more…
item.content:encoded:
An asteroid measuring about a third of a mile (half a kilometer) in diameter will make a relatively close, but harmless pass by Earth Monday night, according to NASA.

This mini-doc about the implications for earth if an asteroid were to collide with our planet, looks at how we share the cosmos with debris from the creation of the solar system. The narrator is Dr Lindsay Keith, Executive Producer of SMASHfestUK.
